canonical_explanation.text: Matter can be classified into pure substances and mixtures. Pure substances have a fixed composition and definite properties. They include elements (like gold, oxygen) and compounds (like water, salt). Mixtures are formed by combining two or more substances physically. The components of a mixture retain their individual properties and can be separated by physical methods. Mixtures can be homogeneous (uniform composition, like salt solution) or heterogeneous (non-uniform composition, like sand and water).
rules: Pure substances have fixed composition throughout
Pure substances have definite physical and chemical properties
Elements and compounds are pure substances
Mixtures are combinations of two or more substances
Components of a mixture retain their properties
Solute dissolves in solvent to form a solution
Mixtures can be separated by physical methods

questions.question_text: A pure substance is one that:
questions.explanation_correct: A pure substance has a fixed composition throughout, which means it contains the same substances in the same proportions everywhere. This allows it to have definite and unchanging properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is correct because a pure substance has a fixed composition. This means it is made up of the same substances in the same amounts everywhere, unlike a mixture which can have variable amounts of its components. Pure substances cannot be easily separated into different substances using simple physical methods.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a pure substance?
questions.explanation_correct: Distilled water is a pure substance because it has a fixed chemical composition and definite properties. It is made up of only water molecules and does not contain any other substances mixed in.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Air, sea water, and milk are all mixtures. Air is a mixture of different gases like oxygen, nitrogen, and carbon dioxide. Sea water contains dissolved salts and other substances. Milk is a complex mixture of fats, proteins, water, and other components. These are not pure substances because their composition can vary.

questions.question_text: Pure gold has the same properties everywhere. This is because:

options.text: Gold is a pure substance with fixed composition

questions.explanation_correct: Pure gold has the same properties everywhere because it is a pure substance. This means it has a fixed composition and definite properties that do not change. This is why pure gold always looks the same, no matter where you find it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is that gold is a pure substance with fixed composition. This means that the atoms and molecules that make up gold are always the same, no matter where you find it. The other options are incorrect because they do not explain why pure gold has the same properties everywhere. Gold being yellow in color or expensive, or gold being a metal, does not fully explain the reason why pure gold is the same everywhere.

questions.question_text: A mixture is:

options.text: A combination of two or more substances

questions.explanation_correct: A mixture is a combination of two or more substances that are physically mixed together. The substances in a mixture retain their individual properties and can be separated by physical methods.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A mixture is not a pure substance. Pure substances have a fixed composition and definite properties, either as an element or a compound. Mixtures are formed by physically combining different substances, and the components can be separated by physical methods. A mixture can be either uniform (homogeneous) or non-uniform (heterogeneous) in composition.

questions.question_text: In a mixture, the components:
questions.explanation_correct: In a mixture, the components retain their individual properties. They are just physically combined, not chemically combined, so each substance keeps its own characteristics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When substances are mixed together, they do not lose their properties. Each component in the mixture keeps its own chemical identity and can be separated out using physical methods. The components do not chemically combine in a mixture.

questions.question_text: When we mix sand and iron filings, we can still separate them using a magnet. This shows that:

options.text: They have retained their individual properties
Iron has lost its magnetic property

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B because when sand and iron filings are mixed, they do not combine chemically. They remain as individual substances and can be separated using a magnet, since iron is magnetic but sand is not.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct. Option A is wrong because the sand and iron filings have not combined chemically, they are just physically mixed. Option C is wrong because iron has not lost its magnetic property. Option D is wrong because sand does not become magnetic when mixed with iron filings.

questions.question_text: A homogeneous mixture is also called:
questions.explanation_correct: A homogeneous mixture is also called a solution because it has a uniform composition throughout. In a solution, the different substances are mixed so evenly that you can't tell them apart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A homogeneous mixture is not a suspension, which is a mixture where solid particles are dispersed in a liquid. It is also not a compound, which is a pure substance with a fixed composition, or an element, which is a pure substance made of only one type of atom. A homogeneous mixture, or solution, is a mixture with a uniform composition that looks the same throughout.

questions.question_text: In a solution, the substance that dissolves is called:
questions.explanation_correct: In a solution, the substance that dissolves is called the solute. The solute is the substance that gets mixed into the solvent to form the solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The solvent is the substance that does the dissolving, not the substance that gets dissolved. The solution is the final mixture that is formed when the solute is dissolved in the solvent. A mixture is a combination of two or more substances that are not chemically bonded, so this is not the correct answer.

questions.question_text: In a solution, the substance in which solute dissolves is called:
questions.explanation_correct: In a solution, the substance in which the solute (the dissolved substance) is dissolved is called the solvent. The solvent is the major component that makes up the solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Solvent. The solute is the substance that gets dissolved in the solvent. The compound refers to a pure substance made up of two or more elements chemically combined. A mixture is a combination of two or more substances that are not chemically combined, so the solvent is not a mixture.

questions.question_text: When sugar dissolves in water, which is the solute?
questions.explanation_correct: Sugar is the solute because it is the substance that dissolves in the water. The water is the solvent, the substance that does the dissolving.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water is not the solute because it is the substance that does the dissolving, not the one that gets dissolved. The sugar is the solute because it is the substance that gets dissolved in the water to form the sugar solution.

questions.question_text: Salt dissolved in water forms a:
questions.explanation_correct: When salt is dissolved in water, it forms a homogeneous mixture. This means the solution has a uniform composition throughout, with the salt evenly distributed in the water. The salt and water cannot be easily separated by physical methods like filtration or decantation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Salt dissolved in water does not form a heterogeneous mixture, as that would mean the solution has uneven composition with visible distinct parts. It also does not form a pure substance or a compound, as a pure substance has a fixed composition and a compound is a new substance formed by chemical reaction. The correct answer is that a salt solution in water forms a homogeneous mixture.

questions.question_text: A heterogeneous mixture is one in which:
questions.explanation_correct: A heterogeneous mixture is one in which the composition is not uniform throughout. This means you can see or identify the different components that make up the mixture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A heterogeneous mixture is not one where the composition is uniform throughout. That would be a homogeneous mixture, where the components are evenly distributed and you can't see them separately. A heterogeneous mixture has different substances that you can visually identify, like sand and water. It's not a pure substance either, as pure substances have a fixed composition.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a heterogeneous mixture?
questions.explanation_correct: Sand and water is a heterogeneous mixture because the sand particles do not dissolve in the water and remain visible as a separate substance. The sand and water have different properties and do not form a uniform solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A salt solution and a sugar solution are both homogeneous mixtures, where the salt or sugar dissolves completely in the water to form a uniform solution. Air is also a homogeneous mixture of different gases like nitrogen, oxygen, and carbon dioxide. In a heterogeneous mixture, the different substances remain distinct and do not dissolve into each other.

questions.question_text: In a mixture of oil and water, we can see two separate layers. This shows that it is a:
questions.explanation_correct: The mixture of oil and water is a heterogeneous mixture because we can clearly see two separate layers, which shows that the components (oil and water) do not mix uniformly. In a heterogeneous mixture, the components retain their individual properties and can be easily separated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mixture of oil and water is not a pure substance because it is not a single, fixed substance. It is also not a homogeneous mixture because the oil and water do not mix evenly. Pure substances have a fixed composition and definite properties, while homogeneous mixtures have a uniform composition throughout. The separate layers of oil and water indicate that this is a heterogeneous mixture.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is TRUE about mixtures?

options.text: They can be separated by physical methods

questions.explanation_correct: Mixtures can be separated by physical methods like filtering, evaporation or distillation because the components retain their individual properties. This allows us to separate the different substances that make up the mixture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mixtures do not have a fixed composition - they are made by combining different substances physically. The components of a mixture keep their own properties and do not lose them. Mixtures are not pure substances, they are a combination of two or more substances.

questions.question_text: Pure water boils at 100 degrees Celsius. Salt water boils at a higher temperature. This shows that:

options.text: Salt water is purer than pure water
Mixtures have different properties than pure substances

questions.explanation_correct: Mixtures have different properties than pure substances because adding another substance (like salt) changes the properties of the mixture. This is why salt water boils at a higher temperature than pure water, showing that mixtures have different properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the boiling point of a mixture being different from a pure substance does not mean the mixture is purer. Option C is incorrect because salt water can definitely boil, just at a higher temperature than pure water. Option D is incorrect because pure water is not a mixture - it is a pure substance.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs are both pure substances?
questions.explanation_correct: Option B is correct because gold and oxygen are both pure substances. Pure substances have a fixed composition and definite properties. Gold is an element, and oxygen is also an element. These are examples of pure substances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, C, and D are not correct because they are mixtures, not pure substances. Air is a mixture of gases, milk and juice are mixtures of various substances, and sea water and tap water are also mixtures. Mixtures have variable composition and can be separated into their individual components by physical methods.

questions.question_text: Air is a homogeneous mixture because:

options.text: We can see different gases in it

questions.explanation_correct: Air is a homogeneous mixture because its composition is the same throughout. The different gases like oxygen, nitrogen, and others are mixed evenly, so you cannot see them separately.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because even though air contains different gases, you cannot see them separately with your eyes. Option C is incorrect because air is not a pure substance - it is a mixture of several gases. Option D is incorrect because air can be separated into its different components using special methods.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a mixture?
questions.explanation_correct: Lemonade is a mixture because it is made by combining different substances like water, lemon juice, and sugar. The components of a mixture retain their individual properties and can be separated by physical methods like filtration or evaporation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pure water and copper are not mixtures. Pure water is a pure substance made up of only water molecules, and copper is a pure element. Common salt, although a pure substance, is not the correct answer because it is a compound, not a mixture.

questions.question_text: A fruit salad is an example of a:
questions.explanation_correct: A fruit salad is a heterogeneous mixture because it contains different fruits, each with its own color, texture, and taste. The components of a fruit salad can be easily separated and identified, unlike a pure substance which has a fixed composition.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A fruit salad is not a pure substance because it is not made of a single element or compound. It is also not a homogeneous mixture, as the different fruits in the salad have distinct properties and are not evenly distributed. A fruit salad is a heterogeneous mixture, as it contains a combination of different fruits with varying shapes, sizes, and flavors.

questions.question_text: Lemon juice mixed with water and sugar forms a:
questions.explanation_correct: Lemon juice mixed with water and sugar forms a homogeneous mixture. This means the mixture has a uniform composition, and you cannot easily tell the different substances apart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lemon juice, water, and sugar do not form a pure substance or a compound. A pure substance has a fixed composition, while a compound is formed by chemically combining two or more elements. Lemon juice, water, and sugar are simply mixed together physically, forming a homogeneous mixture where the individual substances can still be identified.

questions.question_text: Which property best distinguishes a pure substance from a mixture?
questions.explanation_correct: The fixed boiling point is the best way to distinguish a pure substance from a mixture. Pure substances have a definite boiling point, while mixtures have a range of boiling points because they contain different substances with different boiling points.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Color and texture are not reliable ways to distinguish pure substances from mixtures. These physical properties can vary even for pure substances. Weight is also not a good way to tell them apart, as both pure substances and mixtures have a specific weight. The fixed boiling point is the best way to identify a pure substance, as it is a unique property that does not change for that substance.

questions.question_text: Elements and compounds are both:
questions.explanation_correct: Elements and compounds are both pure substances because they have a fixed composition and definite properties. Unlike mixtures, the components of pure substances cannot be separated by physical methods.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Elements and compounds are not mixtures, solutions, or heterogeneous materials. They are pure substances, meaning they have a fixed and unchanging composition. Mixtures can be separated into their components, but pure substances cannot be separated this way.

questions.question_text: Tea is a mixture because:

options.text: It contains water, tea leaves extract, sugar, and milk

questions.explanation_correct: Tea is a mixture because it contains multiple substances like water, tea leaves extract, sugar, and milk. These substances are physically combined, and each substance retains its own properties. This makes tea a mixture, not a pure substance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tea is not a pure substance because it is made up of several different components. The correct answer is that tea is a mixture, as it contains water, tea leaves extract, sugar, and milk, which are all physically combined. The other options, such as tea being brown in color or hot, do not determine whether it is a pure substance or a mixture.

questions.question_text: In a solution of salt and water, which is present in larger amount?
questions.explanation_correct: In a solution of salt and water, the water is present in larger amount. This is because water is the solvent (the liquid that dissolves the salt, which is the solute). The solvent is always present in larger quantity compared to the solute in a solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect option is 'Salt (solute)'. Even though salt is present in the solution, it is not the component that is in larger amount. The water, which is the solvent, is always present in greater quantity than the solute (salt) in a solution.

questions.question_text: Which of the following mixtures would settle if left undisturbed?
questions.explanation_correct: The chalk powder in water mixture would settle if left undisturbed because the chalk powder is a solid that is heavier than the water. The solid particles would sink to the bottom, separating from the water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The salt solution and sugar solution would not settle because the salt and sugar dissolve completely in the water, forming a homogeneous mixture. Air is a mixture of gases that does not have any solid particles that would settle. Only the chalk powder in water mixture has solid particles that are heavier than the liquid, so they would sink and settle at the bottom.

questions.question_text: Common salt (sodium chloride) is a pure substance because:

options.text: It has fixed composition of sodium and chlorine

questions.explanation_correct: Common salt has a fixed composition of sodium and chlorine, so it is a pure substance. The amount of sodium and chlorine in salt never changes, which makes it a substance with a definite composition.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the reasons why common salt is a pure substance. Being white in color, dissolving in water, or being salty are not the defining features of a pure substance. What makes salt a pure substance is that it has a fixed, unchanging composition of its elements - sodium and chlorine.

questions.question_text: Mixtures can have variable composition. This means:

options.text: The proportion of components can be different in different samples

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B because mixtures can have different amounts or proportions of their components. For example, a mixture of sand and water can have different amounts of sand and water in different samples. This makes the composition of mixtures variable or changeable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B. Mixtures do not all have the same composition. The proportion of the components in a mixture can be different in different samples. For example, a mixture of sugar and water can have different amounts of sugar in different glasses. This makes the composition of mixtures variable. Options A, C, and D are incorrect because they do not correctly describe the variable composition of mixtures.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a homogeneous mixture?
questions.explanation_correct: Sand and gravel is not a homogeneous mixture because it has a non-uniform composition. The sand and gravel particles can be easily seen and separated, unlike in a homogeneous mixture where the components are evenly mixed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A salt solution, a sugar solution, and air are all homogeneous mixtures. They have a uniform composition throughout, with the components evenly mixed together. In contrast, sand and gravel is a heterogeneous mixture, where the sand and gravel particles can be clearly seen and separated from each other.

questions.question_text: Soil is an example of a:
questions.explanation_correct: Soil is a mixture because it contains different substances like sand, clay, water, and minerals. The components of soil can be separated by physical methods like filtering or sieving.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Soil is not a pure substance because it is not made of just one type of material. It is also not an element, which is a single type of atom. Soil is also not a compound, which has a fixed composition of different elements combined. Soil is a mixture of many different materials, so the correct answer is that soil is an example of a mixture.

questions.question_text: A pure substance has fixed composition throughout.
questions.explanation_correct: A pure substance has a fixed composition throughout because its particles are all the same. The composition does not change, no matter how much of the substance you have.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. A pure substance has a fixed composition because it is made up of only one type of particle, either an element or a compound. The composition does not change, even if you have a large or small amount of the pure substance.

questions.question_text: In a mixture, the components combine chemically.
questions.explanation_correct: In a mixture, the components do not combine chemically. They are just physically combined and can be separated by physical methods like filtration or evaporation. The components in a mixture retain their individual properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'In a mixture, the components combine chemically' is not correct. In a mixture, the components are only physically combined, not chemically combined. Chemical combination would result in the formation of a new substance with different properties, which is not the case in a mixture.

questions.question_text: A homogeneous mixture has uniform composition throughout.
questions.explanation_correct: A homogeneous mixture has a uniform composition throughout. This means that the mixture looks and feels the same everywhere. The components are evenly distributed, so you can't see or feel the difference between different parts of the mixture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A heterogeneous mixture does not have a uniform composition throughout. In a heterogeneous mixture, you can see or feel the different components that make up the mixture. For example, in a mixture of sand and water, you can see the grains of sand even though they are mixed with the water.

questions.question_text: Sand mixed with water is a homogeneous mixture.
questions.explanation_correct: Sand mixed with water is a heterogeneous mixture, not a homogeneous one. This is because sand and water have different compositions and properties, and you can see the individual sand particles in the mixture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sand and water do not form a homogeneous mixture because they have different compositions and properties. In a homogeneous mixture, the components are completely mixed and you can't see the individual substances. Sand and water have a non-uniform composition, so this is a heterogeneous mixture.

questions.question_text: Mixtures can be separated by physical methods.
questions.explanation_correct: Mixtures can be separated by physical methods because the different components in a mixture retain their individual properties. This means they can be separated using simple physical processes like filtration, evaporation, or distillation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Mixtures can be separated by physical methods because the different substances in the mixture do not chemically combine. Each substance keeps its own properties, so you can use physical processes like filtering or boiling to separate them. This is different from pure substances, which have a fixed composition and cannot be separated by physical means.

questions.question_text: In a sugar solution, sugar is the solvent and water is the solute.
questions.explanation_correct: In a sugar solution, water is the solvent and sugar is the solute. This is because water is the main substance that dissolves the sugar, while sugar is the substance that gets dissolved in the water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'In a sugar solution, sugar is the solvent and water is the solute' is incorrect. The solvent is the substance that dissolves the other substance, and the solute is the substance that gets dissolved. In a sugar solution, water is the solvent because it dissolves the sugar, and sugar is the solute because it gets dissolved in the water.

questions.question_text: Air is a pure substance because it is invisible.
questions.explanation_correct: Air is not a pure substance because it is a mixture of several gases like nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and others. Even though air appears invisible, it is not a pure substance because its composition is not fixed and can vary.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Air is not a pure substance just because it is invisible. Pure substances can be visible or invisible. Air is a mixture of different gases, so it is not a pure substance. The fact that air is invisible does not make it a pure substance.

questions.question_text: Components of a mixture retain their individual properties.
questions.explanation_correct: The components of a mixture retain their individual properties because they are just physically combined, not chemically bonded. This means the substances in the mixture can still be separated by physical methods like filtration, evaporation, etc.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'components of a mixture retain their individual properties' is true. In a mixture, the different substances are only physically combined and do not undergo any chemical changes. This means they can still be separated and the individual properties of each substance are maintained.

questions.question_text: Pure substances have a fixed boiling point while mixtures do not.
questions.explanation_correct: Pure substances have a fixed boiling point because they have a fixed chemical composition. This means that the boiling point is always the same for a pure substance. Mixtures, on the other hand, have varying compositions, so their boiling points can change.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mixtures do not have a fixed boiling point because they are made up of two or more substances. The boiling point of a mixture depends on the individual substances and their amounts in the mixture. So the boiling point can change depending on the composition of the mixture. Pure substances, however, have a fixed chemical composition, so their boiling point is always the same.

questions.question_text: Milk is a heterogeneous mixture because we can see its components.
questions.explanation_correct: Milk is a heterogeneous mixture because you can see different components in it, like the fat globules floating in the liquid. Heterogeneous mixtures have a non-uniform composition, meaning you can see the different parts that make up the mixture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Milk may look like a single, uniform liquid, but it is actually a heterogeneous mixture. This means that even though you can't easily see the different components, milk contains fat globules, proteins, and other substances that are not evenly distributed throughout the liquid. Homogeneous mixtures, on the other hand, have a uniform composition where you can't see the individual components.

questions.question_text: A _______ substance has fixed composition and definite properties.
questions.explanation_correct: A pure substance has a fixed composition and definite properties because its atoms or molecules are all the same. This makes the substance have the same properties every time, like the same melting point, boiling point, and color.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'pure'. A pure substance is not a mixture - it has only one type of substance in it, with no other materials mixed in. This gives it a fixed composition and definite properties that don't change, unlike a mixture which can have varying amounts of different substances.

questions.question_text: A _______ is a combination of two or more substances.
questions.explanation_correct: A mixture is a combination of two or more substances that are physically mixed together. The substances in a mixture keep their individual properties and can be separated by physical methods.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'mixture'. A mixture is a combination of two or more substances that are physically mixed together, like sand and water. The substances in a mixture keep their individual properties and can be separated by physical methods, like filtering or evaporation. The answer 'mixture' is the right choice for this question.

questions.question_text: The substance that dissolves in a solvent is called the _______.
questions.explanation_correct: The substance that dissolves in a solvent is called the solute. This is because the solute is the substance that gets 'dissolved' or mixed into the solvent to form a solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The substance that dissolves in a solvent is called the 'solvent', not the 'solute'. The solvent is the substance that does the dissolving, while the solute is the substance that gets dissolved. The correct answer format is 'solute'.

questions.question_text: The substance in which solute dissolves is called the _______.
questions.explanation_correct: The substance that dissolves in a solution is called the solute. The substance that the solute dissolves in is called the solvent. So, the substance in which the solute dissolves is correctly called the solvent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'solvent'. The solvent is the substance that the solute dissolves in, forming a solution. The solute is the substance that gets dissolved in the solvent. So, the substance in which the solute dissolves is not the solute itself, but the solvent.

questions.question_text: A mixture with uniform composition throughout is called a _______ mixture.
questions.explanation_correct: A homogeneous mixture has a uniform composition throughout, meaning the different substances are evenly mixed and cannot be easily distinguished. This is because the components have been combined physically, not chemically, so they retain their individual properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'homogeneous'. A homogeneous mixture has a uniform composition, which means the different substances are evenly mixed and cannot be easily separated. This is different from a heterogeneous mixture, where the components are not evenly distributed and can be visually distinguished.

questions.question_text: A mixture with non-uniform composition is called a _______ mixture.
questions.explanation_correct: A heterogeneous mixture has a non-uniform composition, meaning the different substances in the mixture are not evenly distributed. This is opposed to a homogeneous mixture, which has a uniform composition throughout.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'heterogeneous'. A heterogeneous mixture is a mixture with a non-uniform composition, where the different substances are not evenly mixed. This is different from a homogeneous mixture, which has a uniform composition. The key difference is that in a heterogeneous mixture, you can see the different components, like sand and water, while in a homogeneous mixture the components are evenly distributed and cannot be easily distinguished.

questions.question_text: Salt dissolved in water forms a _______.
questions.explanation_correct: When salt is dissolved in water, it forms a solution. A solution is a homogeneous mixture where one substance (in this case, the salt) is evenly distributed throughout another substance (the water).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'solution'. Salt dissolved in water does not form a pure substance, but rather a mixture called a solution. In a solution, the salt dissolves evenly in the water, creating a uniform composition. This is different from a heterogeneous mixture, where the components are not evenly distributed.

questions.question_text: Mixtures can be separated by _______ methods.
questions.explanation_correct: Mixtures can be separated by physical methods because the different components in a mixture retain their individual properties. Physical methods like filtration, evaporation, or distillation can be used to separate the components without changing their chemical nature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'physical' because mixtures are made of different substances combined physically, not chemically. The components of a mixture can be separated using physical processes like filtering, boiling, or centrifuging, without changing the chemical properties of the substances. Separating a mixture requires physical methods, not chemical methods that would change the substances themselves.

questions.question_text: Elements and compounds are both examples of _______ substances.
questions.explanation_correct: Elements and compounds are pure substances because they have a fixed composition and definite properties. Pure substances are made up of only one type of particle, unlike mixtures which have more than one type of particle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The answer is 'pure' because elements and compounds are made of a single type of particle that has the same composition throughout. They are not mixtures, which are made by combining two or more substances physically. Mixtures can have varying compositions, but pure substances have a fixed composition.

questions.question_text: In a mixture, the components retain their _______ properties.
questions.explanation_correct: In a mixture, the components retain their individual properties because they are just physically combined, not chemically bonded. This means each component keeps its own characteristics and can be separated by physical methods like filtration or evaporation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'individual'. In a mixture, the components do not lose their original properties. They stay as separate substances and can be separated easily. The components are not chemically combined, so they retain their individual identities and characteristics within the mixture.

questions.question_text: Oil and water form a _______ mixture because they do not mix.
questions.explanation_correct: Oil and water form a heterogeneous mixture because they do not mix together. Heterogeneous mixtures have different parts that are not evenly distributed, so oil and water remain as separate layers when mixed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'heterogeneous'. Oil and water do not mix together to form a uniform solution. Instead, they remain as separate layers, which means they have a non-uniform composition. This type of mixture where the components are not evenly distributed is called a heterogeneous mixture.

questions.question_text: Air is a _______ mixture of gases.
questions.explanation_correct: Air is a homogeneous mixture because it has a uniform composition throughout. The different gases like nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, etc. are evenly distributed in air, so it appears and behaves as a single substance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Air is not a heterogeneous mixture. Heterogeneous mixtures have different components that are not uniformly distributed, like sand and water. Air is made up of different gases but they are evenly mixed, so air is considered a homogeneous mixture. The correct answer is 'homogeneous'.

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to prepare a salt solution:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is 'Take water in a glass', 'Add salt to water', and 'Stir until salt dissolves'. This is the right way to make a salt solution because you need to start with water, then add the salt, and finally stir the mixture until the salt fully dissolves in the water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be 'Stir until salt dissolves', 'Take water in a glass', and 'Add salt to water'. This is not the correct way to make a salt solution because you need to start with water, then add the salt, and finally stir the mixture until the salt fully dissolves. You can't just stir something that doesn't exist yet!

questions.question_text: Arrange from most pure to least pure:
questions.explanation_correct: Distilled water is the purest because it has been treated to remove all impurities. Tap water has some minerals and chemicals added to it, making it less pure than distilled water. Sea water has many dissolved salts and minerals, so it is the least pure of the three.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order from most pure to least pure is not Tap water, Distilled water, Sea water. Distilled water is the most pure because it has been purified to remove all impurities. Tap water has some added chemicals and minerals, making it less pure than distilled water. Sea water has many dissolved salts and other substances, so it is the least pure of the three.

questions.question_text: Arrange in order of increasing uniformity:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order from least to most uniform is: Heterogeneous mixture, Homogeneous mixture, Pure substance. A pure substance has a fixed composition and properties. A homogeneous mixture has a uniform composition, while a heterogeneous mixture has non-uniform composition.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Homogeneous mixture, Heterogeneous mixture, Pure substance. This is wrong because a homogeneous mixture, though uniform in composition, is still a mixture of two or more substances. A pure substance has a fixed composition and is the most uniform. Heterogeneous mixtures, being non-uniform, are the least uniform.

questions.question_text: Arrange in order of ease of separation (easiest to hardest):
questions.explanation_correct: The easiest to separate is the stone from rice, as the stone is a large, solid object that can be easily picked out from the rice. Next, the sand can be separated from the sand-water mixture by letting the sand settle and pouring out the water. Separating the salt from the salt solution is the hardest, as the salt is dissolved in the water and needs to be evaporated to get the solid salt back.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: 'Salt from salt solution', 'Stone from rice', 'Sand from sand-water mixture'. This is wrong because separating the salt from the solution is actually the most difficult, as the salt is completely dissolved in the water. Picking out the stone from rice is the easiest, and separating the sand from the sand-water mixture is easier than the salt solution.

questions.question_text: Arrange these in order of the number of components (fewest to most):
questions.explanation_correct: Pure gold has only one component, so it has the fewest components. Salt solution has two components - salt and water, so it has more components than pure gold. Fruit salad has multiple fruits, so it has the most components of the three options.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order from fewest to most components is: Pure gold, Salt solution, Fruit salad. Pure gold is made of only one element, so it has the fewest components. Salt solution has two components - salt and water. Fruit salad has multiple fruits, so it has the most components.

questions.question_text: How does a pure substance differ from a mixture in terms of composition?

options.text: A pure substance has variable composition, while a mixture has fixed composition
A pure substance has fixed composition, while a mixture has variable composition

questions.explanation_correct: A pure substance has a fixed composition, meaning it always contains the same substances in the same proportions. A mixture, on the other hand, has variable composition because the proportions of its components can change from one sample to another.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the facts. Pure substances always have a fixed composition that does not change, while mixtures can have different amounts of their components in different samples. Options C and D are wrong because pure substances and mixtures differ in this property, so they cannot both be the same.

questions.question_text: How does a homogeneous mixture differ from a heterogeneous mixture in terms of appearance?

options.text: A homogeneous mixture looks the same throughout, while a heterogeneous mixture has visibly different parts
A heterogeneous mixture looks the same throughout, while a homogeneous mixture has visibly different parts

questions.explanation_correct: A homogeneous mixture has a uniform composition and looks the same throughout, like a salt solution where you cannot see the salt separately. A heterogeneous mixture has a non-uniform composition and you can see its different parts, like sand mixed with water where the sand particles are visible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B reverses the definitions. In a homogeneous mixture, the components are evenly mixed and cannot be seen separately. In a heterogeneous mixture, the different components can be observed. Options C and D are incorrect because the two types of mixtures differ in their appearance.

questions.question_text: How does an element differ from a compound as a pure substance?

options.text: An element is made of one type of atom, while a compound is made of two or more types of atoms chemically combined
An element is a mixture, while a compound is a pure substance
A compound is made of one type of atom, while an element is made of many types
Both elements and compounds are made of the same type of atom

questions.explanation_correct: Both elements and compounds are pure substances, but they differ in what they are made of. An element contains only one type of atom, like gold or oxygen. A compound contains two or more types of atoms chemically combined in a fixed ratio, like water (hydrogen and oxygen) or salt (sodium and chlorine).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is wrong because both elements and compounds are pure substances, not mixtures. Option C reverses the definitions. Option D is incorrect because elements and compounds are different in the types of atoms they contain. The key difference is that elements have only one type of atom, while compounds have two or more types chemically bonded together.

questions.question_text: How does a solute differ from a solvent in a solution?

options.text: The solute is always a liquid, while the solvent is always a solid
The solute is the substance that dissolves, while the solvent is the substance in which it dissolves
The solute is always present in larger quantity than the solvent
There is no difference between a solute and a solvent

questions.explanation_correct: In a solution, the solute is the substance that gets dissolved, and it is usually present in a smaller amount. The solvent is the substance that does the dissolving, and it is usually present in a larger amount. For example, when sugar dissolves in water, sugar is the solute and water is the solvent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because a solute can be a solid, liquid, or gas, and so can a solvent. Option C is wrong because the solvent is present in larger quantity, not the solute. Option D is wrong because solute and solvent play different roles in forming a solution.

questions.question_text: How does the boiling point of a pure substance differ from that of a mixture?

options.text: Both have a fixed boiling point
A pure substance has a fixed boiling point, while a mixture boils over a range of temperatures
A mixture has a fixed boiling point, while a pure substance boils over a range

questions.explanation_correct: A pure substance has a definite, fixed boiling point because it has a fixed composition. For example, pure water always boils at 100 degrees Celsius. A mixture does not have a single boiling point and instead boils over a range of temperatures because it contains different substances with different boiling points.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because only pure substances have a fixed boiling point. Option C reverses the facts. Option D is wrong because all liquids, whether pure substances or mixtures, can boil when heated. The key difference is that a pure substance boils at one fixed temperature, while a mixture boils over a range.

questions.question_text: A substance looks the same throughout when observed and its components cannot be seen separately. It is formed by mixing two substances together. This substance is best classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: The substance is a homogeneous mixture because it was formed by mixing two substances together (making it a mixture, not a pure substance) and it looks the same throughout with components that cannot be seen separately (making it homogeneous, not heterogeneous).
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not a heterogeneous mixture because in a heterogeneous mixture you can see the different parts. It is not a pure substance or element because it was formed by mixing two substances together. The description matches a homogeneous mixture, which has a uniform appearance and is made from combining different substances.

questions.question_text: A sample contains two substances that can be easily identified by looking at it, and the different parts are not evenly spread. This sample is best classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: The sample is a heterogeneous mixture because it contains two visible substances that are not evenly spread out. In a heterogeneous mixture, the composition is not uniform, and you can see or identify the different components.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not a pure substance or compound because those have a fixed composition and contain only one type of substance. It is not a homogeneous mixture because in a homogeneous mixture the components are evenly mixed and cannot be seen separately. Since the components are visible and unevenly distributed, this is a heterogeneous mixture.

questions.question_text: A material has a fixed melting point, a fixed boiling point, and the same composition in every sample. This material should be classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: A material with a fixed melting point, a fixed boiling point, and the same composition in every sample is a pure substance. Pure substances have definite physical properties and fixed composition, which is what distinguishes them from mixtures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A homogeneous mixture or solution may look uniform, but it does not have a fixed melting or boiling point and its composition can vary. A heterogeneous mixture has non-uniform composition. Only a pure substance has all three features described: fixed melting point, fixed boiling point, and the same composition in every sample.

questions.question_text: A substance has more than one component, the components can be separated by physical methods, and they retain their own properties. This substance is best classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: This substance is a mixture because it has more than one component, the components can be separated by physical methods, and each component retains its own properties. These are all defining features of a mixture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An element is a pure substance made of one type of atom and cannot be separated by physical methods. A compound is also a pure substance with a fixed composition and cannot be separated by physical methods. A pure substance has only one type of substance in it. The description matches a mixture, where different substances are combined physically and keep their individual properties.

questions.question_text: Riya adds a spoonful of sugar to a glass of warm water and stirs it well. After some time, the sugar disappears and the water tastes sweet throughout. What has Riya made?
questions.explanation_correct: Riya has made a homogeneous mixture (a solution). The sugar dissolved completely in the water, and the sweet taste is uniform throughout the glass. This means the sugar is evenly distributed in the water, which is the defining feature of a homogeneous mixture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not a heterogeneous mixture because the sugar has dissolved and cannot be seen separately. It is not a pure substance because it contains two different substances (sugar and water) mixed together. It is not a compound because sugar and water have not chemically combined to form a new substance. Riya has made a homogeneous mixture, also called a solution.

questions.question_text: Amit is helping his mother in the kitchen. She gives him a bowl of dal (lentil soup) and asks him to observe it. Amit notices that pieces of tomato, onion, and whole spices are floating in the liquid. What type of mixture is the dal?
questions.explanation_correct: The dal is a heterogeneous mixture because Amit can clearly see different components like pieces of tomato, onion, and whole spices floating in the liquid. In a heterogeneous mixture, the composition is not uniform and the different parts can be identified separately.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not a homogeneous mixture because the different ingredients are visible and not evenly distributed. It is not a pure substance because it is made up of many different substances mixed together. It is not a compound because the ingredients are not chemically combined. The dal is a heterogeneous mixture with clearly visible, separate components.

questions.question_text: Priya mixes some iron filings with sand for her science project. Her teacher tells her to separate them. Priya uses a magnet and collects all the iron filings easily. What does this experiment show about mixtures?

options.text: The iron and sand have formed a compound
Components of a mixture retain their individual properties and can be separated by physical methods
Iron loses its magnetic property in a mixture
Sand has become magnetic after mixing

questions.explanation_correct: Priya's experiment shows that components of a mixture retain their individual properties. The iron filings kept their magnetic property even after being mixed with sand, which is why the magnet could pull them out. This also shows that mixtures can be separated by physical methods.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because iron and sand did not chemically combine to form a compound. Option C is wrong because iron did not lose its magnetic property, which is why the magnet worked. Option D is wrong because sand did not become magnetic. The key learning is that in a mixture, each substance keeps its own properties, allowing physical separation.

questions.question_text: Rohan heats two beakers in the school lab. Beaker A contains pure water and Beaker B contains salt water. He notices that Beaker A starts boiling at exactly 100 degrees Celsius, but Beaker B starts boiling at a higher temperature. What can Rohan conclude from this observation?

options.text: Salt water is purer than pure water
Pure substances have a fixed boiling point, while mixtures do not
Beaker B contains a pure substance

questions.explanation_correct: Rohan can conclude that pure substances have a fixed boiling point, while mixtures do not. Pure water boils at exactly 100 degrees Celsius because it is a pure substance with definite properties. Salt water is a mixture, so its boiling point is different and depends on how much salt is dissolved in it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because a higher boiling point does not mean a substance is purer. Option C is wrong because salt water is a mixture, not a pure substance. Option D is wrong because Rohan clearly observed that pure water does boil at 100 degrees Celsius. The correct conclusion is that pure substances have a fixed boiling point, while mixtures do not.

questions.question_text: Meera buys a gold ring from a jeweller. The jeweller tells her it is 24-karat gold, meaning it is made of only gold with nothing else mixed in. Based on this, the gold ring is best described as a:
questions.explanation_correct: Since the jeweller told Meera that the ring is 24-karat gold, meaning it contains only gold and nothing else, the ring is a pure substance. It is made of a single element (gold) with a fixed composition and definite properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the ring contained gold mixed with other metals, it would be a mixture. But 24-karat gold means it is pure gold with no other substances mixed in. A homogeneous or heterogeneous mixture would need two or more substances combined together. Since the ring is made of only one substance, it is a pure substance.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT true about mixtures?

options.text: The components of a mixture retain their individual properties
Mixtures can be separated by physical methods
Mixtures always have a fixed composition
Mixtures are formed by physically combining two or more substances

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that mixtures always have a fixed composition is NOT true. Mixtures have variable composition, meaning the proportions of their components can be different in different samples. For example, you can make a glass of lemonade with more or less sugar each time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and D are all true statements about mixtures. Components of a mixture do retain their properties. Mixtures can be separated by physical methods like filtration or evaporation. Mixtures are formed by physically combining substances. The only false statement is that mixtures have a fixed composition, because mixtures actually have variable composition.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a pure substance?
questions.explanation_correct: Vinegar is NOT a pure substance. It is a mixture of acetic acid and water. Many students think vinegar is a pure substance because it looks like a single clear liquid, but it is actually a homogeneous mixture of two different substances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron is an element and therefore a pure substance. Distilled water is a compound (made of hydrogen and oxygen) and is a pure substance. Common salt (sodium chloride) is a compound and also a pure substance. Only vinegar is a mixture because it contains acetic acid dissolved in water.

questions.question_text: Which of the following CANNOT be used to separate the components of a mixture?
questions.explanation_correct: Melting is not a method used to separate the components of a mixture. Melting simply changes a solid into a liquid by heating it and does not separate different substances from each other. Filtration, evaporation, and using a magnet are all physical methods commonly used to separate mixtures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filtration can separate an insoluble solid from a liquid, like sand from water. Evaporation can separate a dissolved solid from a liquid, like getting salt from salt water. A magnet can separate magnetic substances from non-magnetic ones, like iron filings from sand. Melting, however, only changes the state of a substance and does not separate a mixture into its components.

questions.question_text: Why does sugar disappear when stirred into water?

options.text: Because sugar is destroyed by water
Because sugar particles dissolve and spread evenly throughout the water
Because sugar evaporates into the air

questions.explanation_correct: Sugar disappears when stirred into water because its tiny particles dissolve and spread evenly throughout the water, forming a homogeneous mixture (solution). The sugar is still present in the water, which is why the water tastes sweet, but the particles are too small to be seen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because sugar is not destroyed. It is still present in the water, as you can taste its sweetness. Option C is wrong because sugar does not change into water. The sugar remains as sugar particles that are dissolved. Option D is wrong because sugar does not evaporate into the air. The sugar dissolves in the water and spreads evenly throughout it.

questions.question_text: Why does oil float as a separate layer on top of water instead of mixing with it?

options.text: Because oil is a pure substance and water is a mixture
Because oil does not dissolve in water and is lighter than water
Because oil is heavier than water
Because water evaporates faster than oil

questions.explanation_correct: Oil floats on water as a separate layer because oil does not dissolve in water and is lighter (less dense) than water. Since oil cannot mix with water, the two liquids remain as separate layers, forming a heterogeneous mixture. The lighter oil rises to the top.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because both oil and water can be pure substances, and that is not the reason they do not mix. Option C is wrong because oil is actually lighter than water, which is why it floats on top. Option D is wrong because the rate of evaporation has nothing to do with why oil and water do not mix. The real reason is that oil does not dissolve in water and is less dense.

questions.question_text: Why can the components of a mixture be separated by physical methods?

options.text: Because the components have chemically combined to form a new substance
Because the components are only physically combined and retain their individual properties
Because mixtures contain only one type of substance
Because the components have lost their properties

questions.explanation_correct: The components of a mixture can be separated by physical methods because they are only physically combined, not chemically bonded. Each component keeps its own individual properties, such as its size, weight, or magnetic nature. We can use these different properties to separate them using physical methods like filtration, evaporation, or magnets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because the components of a mixture have not chemically combined. If they had, we would need chemical methods to separate them. Option C is wrong because mixtures contain two or more different substances, not just one. Option D is wrong because the components do not lose their properties. In fact, it is because they retain their properties that we can use those properties to separate them.
